render.tex: \title{Inverse of a Function} \\ %text Inverse of a function and how to compute it %

reason.tex: %text Let us start by using an example to find the inverse of a function. % \begin{align} y&=2x+3 \\ \implies x&=\dfrac{y-3}{2} \\ \end{align} \\ %text If $y = f(x)$, then $x = f^{-1}(y)$ ($f$ inverse of $y$). But if $f^{-1}(y)$ were expressed using the standard convention for functions - $x$ as the independent variable and $y$ as the dependent variable, it would look like this, % \begin{align} f(x) &= 2x + 3 \\ f^{-1}(x) &= \dfrac{x-3}{2} \end{align} \\ %text Speaking generally, for any function $y=f(x)$, the inverse may be expressed as $f^{-1}(x)$ by finding $y$ in terms if $x$ and switching the independent variable. Some examples. % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{ccc} \hline f(x) & f^{-1}(x) \\ \hline mx+c & \tfrac{x-c}{m} \\ x^2 & \sqrt{x},-\sqrt{x} \\ \ln x & e^x \\ \sin x\ & \sin^{-1}x \end{tabular} \end{align}
